title: WCAS INTL_ST 290-0-20 Topics in International Studies
topic: Intro Int'l Dev: Issues and Practice

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces students to both critical and practical perspectives on international development through a combination of readings, lectures, speakers, case studies, written assignments, and oral presentations. Students will learn about the history of international development from its colonial foundations to its present dynamics. In addition to the history, students will explore the ethical dilemmas involved in doing development work, the challenges of measuring development, the relationship between sustainability and development, and the role of identity in development. To complement the historical and theoretical perspectives, students will analyze mechanisms of development -government, private sector, nonprofit sector, and research - through case studies. Every week, students will hear from one or more thought leaders and practitioners working in various sectors of international development.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
? identify and explain the various phases of development and their achievements and shortcomings
? identify and give examples of various mechanisms of development
? develop an informed understanding of the ethical and empirical challenges of development
? develop an improved sense of practice, by designing their own development intervention, according to their experience and interests

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
The main text for the course is Understanding Development by John Rapley, 2nd edition. The book will be available at the bookstore as well as on reserve at the library.
Other readings will be posted on Canvas.
